content.body: Hixie: look at the next table, specifically the table header that contains "Text, E-mail, URL" (re #url vs #url-state)
hmm, <!doctype html><title></title><noscript><style/></style></noscript> is valid html5 (with script)
so is <!doctype html><title></title><noscript><style></noscript>

I want to use links like spotify:search:test but I want some kind of fallback for users that don't have the spotify-protocol registered. Is there anyway to do that? I found the type-attributes for a-tags byt that just gives the browser a hint and there is no way to specify how to fallback. What I want to do is to load a normal http-url which have more information about the spotify-url. Is there anyway to do what I want?
zcorpan: Either would at least cause a few parse errors, wouldn't they?
b
tthorsen: not when scripting is enabled. (the fragment parsing algorithm would then generate parse errors but the spec doesn't say that's an error for the purposes of the content model)
right. I ran them through the html5lib parser, and it agrees that they're alright.
filed http://www.w3.org/Bugs/Public/show_bug.cgi?id=6213
The reason I ask here is that I don't think there is any way so my follow up question would be shouldn't there be a way to fallback.
zcorpan: btw, Validator.nu now builds on Windows (but crashes on startup for a yet unknown reason)
hsivonen: cool
(requires the JAVA_HOME env variable to be set)
can anyone recommend a free simple text editor for windows that uses UTF-8 and LF line breaks?
i use notepad2
though it doesn't handle large files too well
hsivonen PSPad
zcorpan: thanks
csarven: how is PSPad different from notepad2?
PSPad has a softpedia badge, which is not a good sign
pspad seems to have lots of features that notepad2 doesn't, like ftp client
I've heard lots of people say positive things about Notepad++
aaargh. the symlink thing is still the problem
hmm, insertRow() without arguments
acts like insertRow(0) in webkit and opera, acts like insertRow(rows.length) in ie, throws in firefox
an incredible amount of trouble flowing out of using symlinks in the first place and Windows not having them
aaargh. if I use shutil.copytree to copy a tree that contains .svn directories, why isn't shutil.rmtree allowed to remove it?
all-wcprops is access denied
why oh why
hsivonen: Is all-wcprops set as readonly?
I think it's either that or hidden (or both)
but I'm not entirely sure why SVN would choose to do that
Philip`: yes, it has been marked read-only
how am I supposed to delete something I checked out from svn?
hsivonen: By clicking on the folder icon then pressing the delete key then selecting "yes I really want to delete all these files"
Philip`: is that gesture meant to be different from selecting Delete from the context menu?
hsivonen: No - it's just meant to be different to using shutil.rmtree
Philip`: ok. interestingly, for me it did behave differently from the context menu
(context menu failed, delete key worked)
same confirmations and progress UI
Windows <3
Philip`: thanks
hsivonen: Oh, odd
waves from New York :-)
I have to site in the airport for anouther hour before flying to Vegas
s/site/sit/
i'm at JFK terminal 3
I'm at Newark airport
heh
where are you flying to?
home
oh. Where have you been?
new york state, mostly
"vacation"
this is absurd http://www.techdirt.com/articles/20081107/0118162765.shtml
that's the least of haliburton's transgressions
I'm glad they presented that process as a flowchart - I would have found it difficult to follow the dependencies and ordering between the steps if they had simply written it as a list
Philip`: Maybe someone patented patent applications using lists
I hope nobody patents the idea of criticising absurd patents
hmm. It seems the "This idea was invented by Shampoo" thing is turning into a new slashdot meme.
